description: ST. LUCIE COUNTY- Vacation rentals are open for business again. County Administrator Howard Tipton submitted the plan May 20 the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation to re-open rentals, according to an announcement from county spokesman Erick Gill. Two days later, the plan was approved.
text:
ST. LUCIE COUNTY \- Vacation rentals are open for business again.

County Administrator Howard Tipton submitted the plan May 20 the Florida
Department of Business and Professional Regulation to re-open rentals,
according to an announcement from county spokesman Erick Gill.

Two days later, the plan was approved.

Amid the novel coronavirus pandemic, the re-opening of vacation rentals comes
with a handful of restrictions for tourists and employees alike, according to
the county's official plan.

For one, rental reservations from COVID-19 "hot spots" are to be avoided for
the next 30 to 45 days, according to the plan. In addition, rentals cannot
accept reservations from international travelers until further notice.

There is also a 10-person cap on all rentals, according to the plan's
guidelines.

Property owners must also report weekly to the St. Lucie County Tourism Office
a list of reservations, including names, home ZIP codes, arrival and departure
dates, the plan states.

Rental staff members must receive "a wellness check," including a temperature
check upon their arrival at work, according to the plan.

Additionally, guests leaving a vacation rental must turn on all ceiling fans
to circulate the air, according to the plan.

In a statement, Tipton thanked Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and the Florida
Department of Business and Professional Regulation "for their leadership and
quick response to our request to reopen our vacation rentals in a safe and
responsible manner."

Indian River County's plan to reopen vacation rentals was approved Saturday.
The regulations set by that county include no more than 10 guests allowed and
a 24-hour period between guests to ensure enough time for proper cleaning.

Max Chesnes is a TCPalm breaking news reporter. You can keep up with Max on
Twitter @MaxChesnes, email him at
[max.chesnes@tcpalm.com](mailto:max.chesnes@tcpalm.com) and give him a call at
772-978-2224.

title: COVID-19 in St. Lucie County: Vacation rentals are open for business, administrator says
html:
ST. LUCIE COUNTY - Vacation rentals are open for business again.

County Administrator Howard Tipton submitted the plan May 20 the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation to re-open rentals, according to an announcement from county spokesman Erick Gill.

Two days later, the plan was approved.

Amid the novel coronavirus pandemic, the re-opening of vacation rentals comes with a handful of restrictions for tourists and employees alike, according to the county's official plan.

For one, rental reservations from COVID-19 "hot spots" are to be avoided for the next 30 to 45 days, according to the plan. In addition, rentals cannot accept reservations from international travelers until further notice.

There is also a 10-person cap on all rentals, according to the plan's guidelines.

Property owners must also report weekly to the St. Lucie County Tourism Office a list of reservations, including names, home ZIP codes, arrival and departure dates, the plan states.

Rental staff members must receive "a wellness check," including a temperature check upon their arrival at work, according to the plan.

Additionally, guests leaving a vacation rental must turn on all ceiling fans to circulate the air, according to the plan.

In a statement, Tipton thanked Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation "for their leadership and quick response to our request to reopen our vacation rentals in a safe and responsible manner."

Indian River County's plan to reopen vacation rentals was approved Saturday. The regulations set by that county include no more than 10 guests allowed and a 24-hour period between guests to ensure enough time for proper cleaning.

Max Chesnes is a TCPalm breaking news reporter. You can keep up with Max on Twitter @MaxChesnes, email him at max.chesnes@tcpalm.com and give him a call at 772-978-2224.
